rs.title: Life of Hercules
rs.geogName: Hamilton Lodgings, Palace of Holyrood House
rs.note: A series of paintings on the Life of Hercules, mentioned by Pennnant in his description of the Duke of Hamilton's Lodgings at the Palace of Holyrood House. In the third edition of his Tour in Scotland and Voyage to the Hebrides 1772 (London: 1790), pp.245-46, Pennant attributes the paintings to the Flemish artist Jan Gossaert (under the alternative name of John de Mabeuse, however the basis of this attribution is unclear.

rs.title: Henry Stewart, Lord Darnley and his brother Charles Stewart, Earl of Lennox

note.note: Oil on panel. (see here)

rs.title: Picture of Sir Tho. Father to the chancellor

note.note: Catherine, Countess of Desmond, a reputed centenarian living in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. Horace Walpole reported that on the reverse of a copy of the picture at Windsor it was described as 'The Mother of Rembrandt', but Pennant refuted this (as did James Granger) and had the picture engraved for Pennant, A Tour in Scotland 1769 (3rd edn., 1774), p. 74. Richard Bull eventually conceded that the portrait was indeed by Rembrandt, and bore no real relation to the Countess of Desmond. Peltz, 'Bull-Granger Letterbook', pp. 13–14, 115, 117, 123, 124; Thomas Pennant to James Granger, 21 October 1774; Malcolm, Letters [of] Rev. James Granger, p. 157.

Hamilton's Lodgings, Queen's Bedchamber, Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh

note.note: For a print engraved in 1774 by J. Hall from a copy by Moses Griffith, see Pennant, A tour in Scotland 1769 (3rd ed., 1774), and Peltz, 'Engraved Portrait Heads', p. 115. See also original painting in Holyrood Palace.

rs.title: drawing of Sir John Wynn of Gwydir

note.note: For a plate of 'Sir John Wynne, Bart. from the original at Wynne-Stay', engraved by William Sharp, see A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), II, pp. [iii], 140 [Plate III].
A line engraving of Thomas Pennant by John Keyse Sherwin, after Thomas Gainsborough, was published on 1 January 1779. See NPG D19671, here [accessed 1 July 2019].

'The Dance of Death' by Hans Holbein, the younger, was a series of woodblock scenes, created between 1523 and 1525, and showing the allegorical figure of Death accosting individuals from various walks of life. It was an inspiration to later etchers, such as the seventeenth-century Bohemian Wenceslaus Hollar, the Scotsman David Duchar (1743–1827), and the English painter and caricaturist Thomas Rowlandson (1756–1827). See here [accessed 1 July 2019].

note.note:
See watercolour painting of 'Wrexham Town & Church', in Pennant's extra-illustrated
A tour in Wales
(2nd edn., 1784), p. 312/3. John Ingleby may have copied an earlier version of this view for Richard Bull's extra-illustrated copy of the first volume of A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778). See 1009.

See watercolour 'Llangollen Bridge and Town' in Pennant's extra-illustrated
A tour in Wales
(2nd edn., 1784), p. 296/1. The bridge is mentioned in Pennant, A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), pp. 296–7. A copy of this or a similar view by John Ingleby appears to have been created for Richard Bull's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778). See 1009.

Moses Griffith's watercolour painting of Castell Dinas Brân appears in Pennant's extra-illustrated
A tour in Wales
(2nd edn., 1784), p. 296/4. For John Ingleby's watercolour 'Llangollen, Castle Dinas Bran', dated 1793, see here.
Two watercolour drawings of Tower are included in Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), pp. 422/2 and 427.
For a watercolour of Eulo Castle, see Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales (1778), I, p. 84; and A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), p. 87.

Small drawings of the arms of prominent north Wales families are prevalent throughout Pennant's eight-volume extra-illustrated A tour in Wales. Both Moses Griffith and John Ingleby worked on these. See 1009 and 1012; and for Ingleby, employed by Pennant as well as others for small commissions including the copying of coats of arms, see here.

rs.title: Ten supplemental plates to The Journey to Snowdon

note.note: For Moses Griffith's ten supplemental plates to The Journey to Snowdon (1781), see NLW 12710C, where they are bound at the end of the volume; and NLW 12711C, which includes nine out of the ten bound at the end. They were published by Henry Hughes in 1781 as Supplemental plates to the tours in Wales.

rs.title: Head of Charles I
rs.note: Anthony van Dyck (1599–1641), Flemish baroque artist, was estimated to have painted forty portraits of Charles I.

note.note: A watercolour and pen and ink drawing by Moses Griffith of Bangor Ch[urch] (Bangor Is-y-coed, Flintshire), c. 1782, is housed at the National Library of Wales. Watercolours of Bangor (alongside drawings of an owl) appear in both Pennant's extra-illustrated sets of A tour in Wales; see here, p. 229; and here, p. 238.

rs.title: pen and ink drawing of an owl

note.note: This drawing appears to have become a staple of extra-illustrated versions of Pennant's A tour in Wales. It was included at the very end of the first volumes of both Pennant's own extra-illustrated copies of the editions of 1778 and 1784. See here, p. 229; and here, p. 238.
A watercolour drawing of Wynnstay, the seat of Sir Watkin Williams Wynn, fourth baronet, appears in Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales , p. 229.

rs.title: print of Thomas Mowbray
rs.note: See 'The Challenge between the Duke of Hereford and Thomas Mowbray duke of Norfolk, taken from the beautiful MS. of Froissart, in the Harleian library, marked 4380', in The journey from Chester to London (1782), Plate IX at p. 167.

note.note: For a portrait of Margaret Clifford (née Russell), Countess of Cumberland, see Pennant, The journey from Chester to London, Plate XIII at p. 246.

rs.title: portrait of Katherine Howard, Countess of Suffolk

note.note: See Pennant, The journey from Chester to London (1782), Plate XI at p. 228+, engraved by J. Caldwell. The original oil on canvass drawing, dated 1620 and attributed to Sir Nathaniel Bacon, is still at Gorhambury. Ex inf. Jane O'Grady, Gorhambury Estates Co.

rs.title: monument of Richard Herbert and his wife

note.note: For Pennant's notice of this monument, see A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), p. 374: 'Within [the church of St Nicholas, Montgomery] is a handsome monument of Richard Herbert, Esq; ... represented in armour; and by him lies his lady, Magdalene, daughter of Sir Richard Newport of High Arcol. In front are their numerous progeny. He died in 1597. The monument was erected by his lady, who survived him several years ...'.

note.note: This is included in Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales. See here, p. 351/2.
Catherine Cornaro was the last Queen of Cyprus, reigning from 1474 to 1489. Portraits of her were painted by Durer, Titian, Bellini and Giorgione.

For a seventeenth-century portrait in oil on canvas of Sir Peter Mutton (1585–1637), see here [accessed 17 June 2019]. Depicting the subject in black robes with a white ruff, this does not correspond to the portrait of Mutton described by Pennant in A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778), II, p. 342, where he is said to be dressed in 'scarlet robes, a ruff, and great hat', and no portrait by Moses Griffith has been identified. On Mutton generally, see ODNB; Hist P.

rs.note: Published in The Westminster Magazine; For December, 1777.

rs.title: Print of Admiral Seymour
rs.note: Thomas Seymour, Baron Seymour of Sudely (b. in or before 1509, d. 1549), was appointed lord high admiral in 1547. The Victoria and Albert Museum houses a 1920s collotype after 'Portrait of an Unknown Man, possibly identifiable as Thomas Seymour', by Hans Holbein, the younger.

rs.title: Print of William Penderel and the Royal Oak
rs.note: Numerous prints were published depicting Charles II's concealment, on 6 and 7 September 1651, in an oak tree at Boscobel House in Shropshire. He was provided with pillows to rest on and food by the caretaker of Boscobel, William Penderel (c.1609–1700), and his wife Joan (d.1669). *ODNB*; and engraving entitled 'William Pendrill and the Royal Oak; the tree in Boscobel House, Shropshire, in which King Charles II and Colonel Carlos hid whilst fleeing following his defeat at the Battle of Worcester in 1651.'

rs.title: Portrait of Anthony Henley
rs.note: Anthony Henley (1666/7–1711), wit and politician, was the subject of portraits in oils by G. Kneller, together with two mezzotints (1688 and 1694) by J. Smith, and a portrait by W. C. Edwards, n.d., all after Kneller. *ODNB*.

rs.title: Portrait of the Earl of Cumberland
rs.note: Numerous portraits were made of George Clifford, third earl of Cumberland (1558–1605), courtier and privateer. ODNB; and for examples of line engravings, see http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?searchText=george+clifford [accessed 21 September 2018]. Pennant mentions Clifford's wife, Margaret, countess of Cumberland, in The journey from Chester to London (1782) (see 1013), and gives an account of both in A tour in Scotland 1772, part II (1776), pp. 354–5.

rs.title: Portrait of the Earl of Arundel
rs.note: The earldom of Arundel was created for the Norman baron Sir William d'Aubigny in 1138, and was held by the dukes of Norfolk at the time Bull referred, in 1786, to a portrait of an unspecified Earl of Arundel.

rs.title: Portrait of Humphrey Llwyd
rs.note: Humphrey Llwyd (1527–1568), Welsh antiquary and map maker. Anonymous 1561 portraits are housed at NMG Wales and NLW; a stipple by R. Clamp and a mezzotint by J. Faber at BM and NPG, both undated. *ODNB*.

rs.title: a "foolish scratch of Hogarth's" engraved on a snuff box

note.note: Described by Richard Bull as a 'foolish scratch', this work may possibly be identified with a small oval print for Pope's Rape of the Lock, engraved on the lid of a snuff-box. John Nichols noted that a 'few impressions only were taken' of it and considered it 'one of the poorest of Hogarth's performances'. ODNB; John Nichols, Biographical Anecdotes of William Hogarth, with a catalogue of his works chronologically arranged; and occasional remarks (3rd edn., enlarged and corrected, London: John Nichols, 1785), p. 423.

rs.title: drawing of the Priory of Dunstable

note.note: Carter's interest in Dunstaple Priory Church is indicated by his notice of it in Gentleman's Magazine (May, 1805), 428, quoted in John Britton, The architectural antiquities of Great Britain represented and illustrated in a series of views, elevations, plans, sections, and details, of ancient English edifices: with historical and descriptive accounts of each (5 vols., London: printed for Longman, Hurst, Rees and Orme, J. Taylor and the author, 1807–26), I, p. 8. A drawing and plan of 'The Western Front of The Priory Church, Dunstaple, Bedfordshire' in ibid. can probably be attributed to Carter.

rs.title: The arms of the Earl of Salisbury
rs.note: See Pennant's extra-illustrated *A tour in Wales 1770 [1773]* (1778), I, p. 93 at http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4691918.

rs.title: View of Nanny House
rs.note: Pennant's extra-illustrated *A Journey to Snowdon*, at http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4692660, p. 106, includes the arms in the margin opposite letterpress on Nanney, 'the antient seat of the antient family of the Nanneys, now of the Vaughans', but no drawing of the house itself. For a drawing by Moses Griffith of the house ('Nannau'), dated August 1805, see NLW, Moses Griffith collection (Box 3) (Size B).

rs.title: Chief Justice Glynne
rs.note: Sir John Glynne (1603–66), judge and politician, negotiated successfully the turbulent years of civil war and restoration in Britain to carve out a successful career and emerge a wealthy man. Pennant's full account of his life is given in *A tour in Wales* (2nd edn., 1784), pp. 105–8. For a drawing see ibid., Plate XII, 'Chief Justice Glynne', engraved by J. Caldwall. A small oval drawing in pencil in Pennant's extra-illustrated *A tour in Wales* (2nd edn., 1784), at http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4690846, p. 106, may also be of Glynne.

rs.title: Portrait of David Gamm
rs.note: For Pennant's relation of the treachery of Dafydd [David] Gam (d.1415) towards Owain Glyn Dŵr, see *A tour in Wales* (2nd edn., 1784), pp. 359–60. The arms of Dafydd Gam are included in Pennant's extra-illustrated *A tour in Wales*, at http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4692237, p. 363, but no portrait is given.

rs.title: Fisherwick House
rs.note: This work has not been identified, but see further Fisherwick House.

rs.title: Don Alphonso de la Curva, Marquis of Bedmar
rs.note: Alfonso de la Cueva-Benavides y Mendoza-Carrillo, marqués de Bedmar (1574–1655), cardinal in the Catholic church and bishop of Malaga. For an image now at the Museo del Prado see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfonso_de_la_Cueva,_1st_Marquis_of_Bedmar#/media/File:El_cardenal_Alfonso_de_la_Cueva,_marqu%C3%A9s_de_Bedmar_(Museo_del_Prado).jpg [accessed 29 August 2018].

rs.title: Gómez Suárez de Figueroa y Córdoba, first Duke of Feria
rs.note: Gómez Suárez de Figueroa y Córdoba, first Duke of Feria (1520?–71). He accompanied Philip II of Spain on his visit to England in 1554 to marry Mary I of England.

rs.title: John de Velasco, Duke of Fria’s
rs.note: Juan Fernández de Velasco, fifth Duke of Frías (c.1550–1613).

rs.title: José de Gálvez y Gallardo
rs.note: José de Gálvez y Gallardo, marqués de Sonora (1720–87), was appointed minister for the Indies in 1775 and held the post until 1787. For an image see https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jos%C3%A9_de_G%C3%A1lvez.jpg [accessed 29 August 2018].

rs.title: Pedro Téllez-Girón
rs.addName: Don Pedro Giron, Duke of Ossuna
rs.note: Pedro Téllez-Girón, third Duke of Osuna (1574–1624). For a portrait by Bartolomé González y Serrano, baroque portrait painter at the court of Philip II, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedro_T%C3%A9llez-Gir%C3%B3n,_3rd_Duke_of_Osuna#/media/File:Pedro_T%C3%A9llez-Gir%C3%B3n_y_Velasco.jpg [accessed 29 August 2018].

rs.title: Maximilien de Béthune
rs.addName: Marquis of Rosni; Duke de Sully
rs.note: Maximilien de Béthune, first Duke of Sully, Marquis of Rosny and Nogent, Count of Muret and Villebon, Viscount of Meaux (1560–1641). For a print from the collections of the Peace Palace Library, The Hague, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximilien_de_B%C3%A9thune,_Duke_of_Sully#/media/File:Charles-Iren%C3%A9e-Castel-de-Saint-Pierre-Projet-de-trait%C3%A9-pour-rendre-la-paix_MG_0660.tif [accessed 29 August 2018].

rs.title: Monastry of St. Juste
rs.note: Monastery of Yuste (known in older works as San Yuste or San Just) in the province of Cáceres, Extremadura, Spain, was founded in 1402.

rs.title: Don Bernardo Sandoval, Archbishop of Toledo
rs.note: Bernardo de Sandoval y Rojas (1546–1618) became Archbishop of Toledo in 1599. For an image see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernardo_de_Sandoval_y_Rojas#/media/File:Bernardo_de_Sandoval_y_Rojas.jpg [accessed 29 August 2018].

rs.title: Duke of Gandía
rs.note: The 'duke of Gandía' was a hereditary Spanish title created in 1399.

rs.title: Conde de Lemos
rs.note: The 'Conde de Lemos' is a title in the Spanish nobilty, which came into being in 1456.

note.note: For the arms of the Jones family of Halkin, which incorporate ducal and baronial pendents derived from their connection with the Luttrells, see A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), here, p. 75.

rs.title: Four Apostles
rs.note: For 'four portraits of great merit' representing the evangelists at Broadlane House, Hawarden, see *A tour in Wales* (2nd edn., 1784), p. 105. Pennant names the artist as the Frenchman Valentine (Valentin de Boulogne; 1591–1632) in the text, adding in a note at the foot of the page that 'A gentleman well skilled in prints tells me, that these four pictures were engraven by Rousselet'. Pennant's extra-illustrated *A tour in Wales* (2nd edn., 1784), includes portraits of the evangelists at http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4690846, pp. 104, 105. On de Boulogne, see https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/artists/valentin-de-boulogne [accessed 12 September 2018].

rs.title: Gaston de Foix
rs.note: Gaston III, Count of Foix (1331–1391).

rs.title: Rolando slain in the field of Roncevaux
rs.note: Roland (d. 778), a Frankish military leader under Charlemagne, died at the battle of Roncevaux, a high mountain pass in the Pyrenees, on the border between France and Spain.

rs.title: head of De Buffon
rs.note: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon (1707–88), French naturalist and author of the monumental *Histoire naturelle, générale et particulière* (36 vols., 1749–88; add. vol., 1789). For Pennant's account of time spent with de Buffon during his continental tour of 1765, see *Literary life*, pp. 4–5. A 1776 print of de Buffon is included in Bull's extra-illustrated MS 'Literary life', NLW 5502E.

rs.title: head of Voltaire
rs.note: An engraving by Peter Mazell of Voltaire at his desk is included in Pennant's extra-illustrated manuscript copy of *Literary life*, NLW 12706E. Bull's copy of the same work, NLW 5502E, includes a full face and bust portrait, engraved after a court portrait of 1736 ('Gravé d'après celui de la Cour peint en 1736').

rs.title: head of von Haller
rs.note: Pennant made the acquaintance of the Swiss anatomist and physiologist Albrecht von Haller (1708–77) at Bern during 1765, and corresponded with him between 1773 and 1778. WCRO, CR 2017/ TP 245/1–8; *Literary life*, p. 6. Bull included two and Pennant one print of Haller in their MS copies of *Literary life* (NLW 12706E; NLW 5502E).

note.note: The soldier John Cornewall, Baron Fanhope (d.1443), was reputedly born on board a ship travelling from Brittany to England. He received the patronage of both Richard II and Henry IV, marrying the latter's sister, Elizabeth of Lancaster. ODNB. An etching showing Sir John and Elizabeth of Lancaster was produced by Wenceslas Hollar.

rs.title: Delvin formerly Inch-Stuthil
rs.geogName: Pennant, A tour in Scotland, and voyage to the Hebrides; MDCCLXXII. Part II (London: 1776), Plate VII.

note.note: Engraved by Peter Mazell. See also William Roy, Military Antiquities of the Romans in North Britain (1793).

rs.title: Etching, possibly of one of the gates of Edinburgh
Forres
rs.note: A Grant del.", "F. Cary Sculp."

rs.title: Portrait of Thomas Cranmer
rs.note: Thomas Cranmer, Archbishop of Canterbury (1469–1556).

rs.title: Thomas Cranmer
rs.surname: Vertue, after Hans Holbein, the younger

note.note:
Line engraving of an un-bearded Thomas Cranmer, Archbishop of Canterbury. See here
[accessed 19 September 2018].

rs.title: etching of Church of St Margaret's, near Lincoln Cathedral

note.note: For the Church of St Margaret, in the parish of Quadring, Lincolnshire, see here [accessed 24 September 2018]. The etching, entitled 'St Margaret's, near Lincoln Cathedral', appears in Richard Bull's extra-illustrated manuscript copy of Literary life (NLW 5502E).

rs.title: etching of Mapleton Church near Ashbourn Derbyshire

note.note: Mapleton (sometimes spelt ‘Mappleton’), village near the town of Ashbourne in Derbyshire. The church of St Mary, first mentioned during the reign of Edward I, was rebuilt in the mid-18th century. See here [accessed 24 September 2018]. For the etching, see 'Mapleton Church near Ashbourn Derbyshire', in Richard Bull's extra-illustrated manuscript copy of Literary life (NLW 5502E).

rs.title: Lady Margaret Cecil, Countess of Ranelagh

note.note: See Pennant's extra-illustrated Continuation of the Journey, part II (1783), here, p. 417/1.

rs.title: Caer Caradoc
rs.geogName: Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales, FIVE: Acton Burnel, facing p. 421
rs.note: Wash drawing.

rs.title: parts of Fountains abby
rs.note: Pennant's extra-illustrated manuscript Literary life, p. 33, notes that Moses Griffith produced etchings of 'two beautiful parts of Fountains-abby': these are included in both Pennant and Bull's extra-illustrated copies. See NLW 12706E, NLW 5502E.

rs.title: flogging scene of Henry II
rs.addName: King Henry II whipped by the Pope’s Order
rs.note: This refers to 'King Henry II whipped by the Pope’s Order' from Robert Burton, Wonderful Prodigies of Judgement and Mercy (1685).

rs.title: American birds
rs.note: On Moses Griffith's etching of 'about a dozen North American birds' as private plates, see Pennant's extra-illustrated manuscript Literary life, NLW 12706E, p. 33.

rs.title: Andrea Doria
rs.note: Andrea Doria (or D’Oria) (1466–1560), Genoese mercenary captain naval commander credited with re-establishing Genoese Independence after domination by the French.

rs.title: Sebastian King of Portugal
rs.note: Dom Sebastian I (1554–78), King of Portugal and the Algarves from 1557 to 1578. He disappeared (presumably killed in action by the forces of Abd Al-Malik) at the battle of Alcácer Quibir in northern Morocco, but uncertainty over his fate led to a belief that he had survived and would return. Fraudulent claims to be Sebastian made by men in Portugal, especially during the time of the Iberian Union, 1580–1640.

rs.title: the Great Emanuel
rs.note: Manuel I (1469–1521), the Fortunate, King of Portugal and the Algarves, known as Emanuel the Great, King of Portugal, ascended the throne 1495.

rs.title: Philip of Spain
rs.note: There were five Spanish kings named Philip before the abdication of Philip V in 1746.

rs.title: Marquis of Denia, Duke of Lerma
rs.note: Francisco Gómez de Sandoval, Marquis of Denia and Duke of Lerma. For an 'Equestrian Portrait of the Duke of Lerma' by Peter Paul Rubens now housed at the Museo del Prado see here [accessed 29 August 2018].

rs.title: [Our Saviour raising Lazarus]
rs.note: The title given above is taken from Pennant's description of this picture as 'a most exquisite [picture], by an unknown hand, of our Saviour raising Lazarus' in A tour in Wales (1778), II, p. 417.

rs.title: The Denial of St Peter
rs.note: Pennant describes 'A large picture of St. Peter denying our Lord . . . a fine performance, by Gerard Honthurst', viewed at Longnor Hall, in A tour in Wales (1778), II, p. 417.

rs.title: heads representing Fire, Water, and Air

note.note: The reference to ‘Three Heads representing Fire Water and Air’ in Hester Piozzi's Scottish tour may refer to Albani’s allegorical landscape paintings, in which the four elements form a cycle of images. See Catherine R. Puglisi, Francesco Albani: Albani and his Critics (Yale UP, 1999), pp. 19-23.

rs.title: two Roman Emperors, of which one Vetellius

note.note: Vitellius (AD15-AD69) ruled the Roman Empire for eight months in AD69. Persid’s rosso is a red marble.
Representation of a syncretic Greco-Roman god, alternately associated with farming and with the underworld.
A representation of Pallas Athena, Greek goddess of wisdom and war.

rs.title: Cenotaph to Elizabeth late Duchess of Northumberland’s Memory

note.note: An artwork imagined or proposed by Hester Piozzi, as a memorial to Elizabeth Percy (née Seymour; 1716-76), Duchess of Northumberland. Charlemagne, or Charles the Great (?747-814) was King of the Franks from 768 and became Roman Emperor in 800.

rs.title: The Lives of Saint Anthony, Saint Austin & Saint Cuthbert

note.note: Painted in Carlisle Cathedral. For photographs of these late 15th-century panels depicting the saints Anthony, Augustine and Cuthbert see: https://www.carlislecathedral.org.uk/the_painted_panels

rs.title: Drawings related to George Low's Tour of Orkney and Shetland
rs.note: Received by Pennant and worked-up by Moses Griffith. A selection appeared as plates III-V in Pennant's Arctic Zoology (1784). See also Low, 'Bird-catching in one of the Orkney isles'.

rs.title: Christ delivering the keys to St Peter

note.note: An etching of this painting by Van Dyck is held at the Knowsley Gallery in the British Museum.

rs.title: View of Iona, from the sound
rs.geogName: Thomas Pennant, A tour in Scotland and voyage to the Hebrides 1772 (Chester: 1774), plate XXII, p.289.

rs.title: Loch-Ranza bay, and the manner of taking the basking shark
rs.geogName: Thomas Pennant, A tour in Scotland and voyage to the Hebrides 1772 (Chester: 1774), plate XIII, p.192

note.note: Rembrandt’s Belshazzar’s Feast (c. 1636/8) is now held at the National Gallery; see https://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/rembrandt-belshazzars-feast

rs.title: Tom bell
rs.note: Famous bell in the tower of the Church of Christ Church College Oxford.

rs.title: Noli me tangere
rs.note: Altar piece painted for All Souls College Chapel in Oxford.

rs.title: Window with Sir Joshua's designs painted by Jarvis
rs.note: Window in Oxford's New College Chapel.

rs.title: Altarpiece in New College Oxford
rs.note: The sculpture consists of five compartments over the Communion Table, representing in Marble Altorelivo 1. The Salutation of the Virgin Mary. 2 the Nativity of our Saviour. 3. The taking down from the Cross. 4. The Resurrection. 5. The Ascension. They were done by a famous Artist Mr. Westmacott.

rs.title: Mary Queen of Scots
rs.note: In the Bodleian's Picture Gallery.

rs.title: Self-portrait of Titial
rs.note: Part of the collection of pictures General Guise presented to Christ Church College.

rs.title: The Butcher’s Shop
rs.note: The Biblical story of Susanna and the Elders was painted by various artists in the period, including Tintoretto (see below), however the painting held at Christ Church is by Giulio Cesare Procaccini (1574-1625): see https://artuk.org/discover/artworks/susanna-and-the-elders-229177

rs.title: Portrait of the Duke of Alva & a Venetian Nobleman
print of Dom Sebastian
rs.note: Dom Sebastian I (1554–1578), King of Portugal and the Algarves from 1557 to 1578. He disappeared (presumably killed in action by the forces of Abd Al-Malik) at the battle of Alcácer Quibir in northern Morocco, but uncertainty over his fate led to a belief that he had survived and would return. Fraudulent claims to be Sebastian made by men in Portugal, especially during the time of the Iberian Union, 1580–1640.

rs.title: Charles V
rs.note: Charles V, ruler of the Habsburg Netherlands from 1506, the Spanish Empire from 1516 and the Holy Roman Empire, from 1519.

rs.title: Philip II
rs.note: Philip II (1527–98), became king of Spain in 1556, but was also known as Philip I of Portugal from 1581.

rs.title: the present King & Queen of Spain
rs.note: Charles IV, king of Spain from 1788 until 1808, and his wife from 1765, Maria Louisa, daughter of Philip, Duke of Parma.

rs.title: Heemskirk
rs.note: Jacob van Heemskerk (1567–1607), Dutch explorer, then admiral in command of the Dutch fleet at the 1607 battle of Gibraltar. In this battle, he successfully led an unexpected attack on the Spanish fleet, anchored at the Bay of Gibraltar, but was killed by a cannon ball wound to his leg. See here [accessed 27 September 2018].

rs.title: 'Mrs Woods; Sarah Siddons (née Kemble); Mr Sutherland in Hume's "Douglas"'
rs.note: A 1784 etching and aquatint relating to John Hume's blank verse tragedy, (1756). See National Portrait Gallery, NPG D16860, at here[accessed 28 September 2018].

rs.title: The Rev John Lloyd
rs.note: Engraved by Peter Mazell. This appears in volumes extra-illustrated by both Pennant and Bull. See Pennant, A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784) @ http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4692237, p. 454/2; Pennant, Literary life, extra-illustrated by Pennant (NLW 12706E) and by Bull (NLW 5502E).

rs.title: prints of English birds
rs.addName: etchings of Birds, by Moses Griffyths [sic]

rs.title: bust of Charles I
rs.note: Commissioned by Charles I, Gianlorenzo Bernini's sculptural bust of the king was produced from a triple portrait of the latter by Van Dyck. It was probably destroyed in a fire at the palace of Whitehall in 1698, but copies in the form of engravings and bronze sculptures survive. Rudolf Wittkower, Bernini: The Sculptor of the Roman Baroque (London: Phaidon Press, 1997), p. 258. Pennant includes Peter Mazell's drawing and engraving of it 'From an Original Bronze by Bernini, From a Picture by Vandyke', in Some account of London (1791), facing title page.

rs.title: View of London at the fire
rs.note: See Pennant, Some account of London (1791), p. 324, for 'A View of Part of London as it appeared in the Great Fire of 1666'. This work can be identified with the painting at the Painter Stainers' Hall, described in ibid., p. 343, as 'the fire of London, by Waggoner'. Further on the 'obscure name' of the painter and his connection with this work, see Horace Walpole, Anecdotes of painting in England; with some account of the principal artists; and incidental notes on other arts (4 vols., Strawberry-Hill, 1762), III, p. 55.

rs.title: A view of London in the reign of Elizabeth
rs.note: This may be identified with 'London and Westminster in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, Anno Dom. 1563' in Pennant, Some account of London (1791), front matter.

rs.title: Bird-catching in one of the Orkney isles
rs.geogName: Thomas Pennant, Arctic Zoology. Vol. I. Introduction. Class I. Quadrupeds. (London: 1784), Plate IV, XXX,

note.note: Oil on canvas; National Museum of Wales, NMW A 97. See here [accessed 7 August 2018]. For a print of this drawing in Pennant's extra-illustrated *A tour in Wales* (2nd edn., 1784), I, p. v, see http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4690846.

rs.title: 21 plates from Antiquities and Scenery of the North of Scotland, in a Series of Letters to Thomas Pennant (London: 1780)
'De Spaanse, Engelse en Hollandse vloten voor Deal, 1639'
rs.addName: battle in the Down 1636 between Vantromp & oquendo
rs.note: The Battle of the Downs, off the English coast between Dover and Deal, was fought on 21 October 1639. The Spanish under Admiral Antonio de Oquendo were defeated by the United Provinces, led by Lieutenant-Admiral Maarten Tromp. For the engraving by Wenceslaus Hollar, 'De Spaanse, Engelse en Hollandse vloten voor Deal, 1639' (1640), see the two images (one showing the right hand and the other the left hand view of the navies), at here and here [accessed 1 October 2018].

rs.title: Lady Salisbury
rs.note: 'Lady Salisbury' and 'Lady S.', portraits of whom are referred to by Pennant in 1129, may be Margaret Pole (1473–1541), suo jure countess of Salisbury, whose husband, Richard Pole, died in 1504. ODNB. For a portrait by an unknown artist, entitled ‘unknown woman, formerly known as Margaret Pole, Countess of Salisbury’, oil on panel, c.1535, see National Portrait Gallery, NPG 2607, at here [accessed 1 October 2018].

rs.title: Portrait of Douglas, 8th Duke of Hamilton (1756 -1799)

note.note: A portrait of Benjamin Stillingfleet in oil on canvas by Johann Joseph Zoffany, c. 1761, together with examples of mezzotints by Valentine Green, after Zoffany, 1782, are found at NPG. See here [accessed 1 October 2018]. Pennant included a print, with a cutting from the colophon of a letter and Stillingfleet's signature in his extra-illustrated MS copy of Literary life (NLW 12706E).
Prints of 53 heads brought from Paris to Pennant by David Pennant.

rs.title: head of the Duke of Wharton

note.note: For Philip James Wharton, Duke of Wharton and Jacobite Duke of Northumberland (1698–1731), rake and politician, see ODNB. NPG houses several portraits ‘after Charles Jervas’ and two line engravings by George Vertue (publ. 1732), among others. There does not appear to be a reference to this duke in Pennant's first three editions of Of London (1790) / Some account of London (1791, 1793), however, and Pennant may have meant either Robert de Wharton, rewarded by Henry VIII in 1539 by a handsome pension and by the bishoprick of St Asaph (Some account of London (1791), p. 56), or Philip, lord Wharton, to whose wife he refers (Some account of London (1793), p. 129).

rs.title: small head of the Earl of Essex

note.note: Robert Devereux, second Earl of Essex (1565–1601), soldier and politician. A firm favourite of Elizabeth I, Devereux led an insurrection against her on 8 February 1601, and was executed for treason. Pennant, in Some account of London (1791), p. 377, writes how Elizabeth, 'giving way to a most ungenerous passion, caused from [the] pulpit [of Paul's Cross] the memory of her once-beloved Essex to be blackened'. ODNB cites a miniature attributed to N. Hilliard, c.1587, at the NPG. This is not featured on the NPG website, where there is only a watercolour and bodycolour on vellum, c.1595, attributed to Nicholas Hilliard's studio. See here [accessed 2 October 2018]. For a miniature portrait of Devereux (51mm x 41mm, oval), by Isaac Oliver, after 1596, see here [accessed 2 October 2018].

rs.title: small head of Sir Walter Ralegh

note.note: Sir Walter Ralegh (1554–1618), courtier, explorer and author, executed for treason. ODNB. Ralegh is mentioned by Pennant in Of London (1790), pp. 81, 133, and a further reference to his imprisonment in the Tower appears in the second edition of the same work, Some account of London (1791), p. 293. A watercolour oval miniature engraving by Nicholas Hilliard, c.1585, is found at NPG. See here [accessed 2 October 2018].

Maarten Tromp (1598–1653), officer then admiral in the Dutch navy. For Pennant's account of his involvement in the 1639 battle of the Downs, see Pennant, From London to Dover (1801), pp. 174–5. Portraits of Tromp at NPG include a mid seventeenth-century etching, probably by Wenceslaus Hollar (here [accessed 2 October 2018]), and a mid eighteenth-century engraving by Jacobus Houbraken, after Aert Schouman (here [accessed 2 October 2018]). Neither these nor further unattributed line engravings at NPG are described as miniatures.
For a print of Jacob van Heemskerk by A. Schouman, engraved by J. Houbraken, and dated 1693, see here [accessed 2 October 2018].

rs.title: old London markets
rs.addName: A very odd M. S. ... respecting the markets of London 1598

note.note: This may be identified with Folger MS V.a.318, housed at the Folger Shakespeare Library, and entitled 'A caveatt for the citty of London, or, A forewarninge of offences against penall lawes, 1598', which includes diagrams of markets within the city of London, together with pictures of the officials in charge of them. The author is named as Hugh Alley. For a printed edition, see Hugh Alley’s Caveat: The Markets of London in 1598, ed. Ian Archer, Caroline M. Barron and Vanessa Harding (London: London Topographical Society, 1988).

rs.title: Miniature of Mary, Queen of Scots (1542-87)

The van Kronenburgh portrait is at here [accessed 28 August 2018].

rs.note: This portrait of Cranmer, un-bearded, is found in Robert Thoroton, The antiquities of Nottinghamshire, extracted out of records, original evidences, leiger-books other manuscripts, and authentic authorities (2nd edn., Nottingham: G. Burbage, 1790), I, p. 262. See Granger's recommendation of it in A biographical history of England, I, p. 95: 'There is a good head of him, after Holbein, in Thoroton's "Nottinghamshire;"[sic]'.

note.note: Sir John Packington (1549–1625), courtier, knighted by Elizabeth I in 1587. ODNB. Copies of a drawing of Packington were made by Moses Griffith from an original at Bevere, Worcestershire, for both Pennant and Bull, with the latter's version used as the basis of an engraving by Harding. For Bull's use of his own version by Moses Griffith, see his copy of 'A journey from London to Dover' at the Museum of London, Port of London Authority Collection, I, facing f. 15; for the published engraving, see From London to Dover (1801), following p. 12; for a discussion of the drawing and its engraving, Lucy Peltz, Facing the text: Extra-illustration, print culture, and society in Britain 1769–1840 (San Marino, CA: Huntington Library, Arts Collections, and Botanical Gardens, 2017), pp. 233–5.

rs.title: two prints of Catherine of Aragon

note.note: Catherine of Aragon (1485–1536), the first wife of Henry VIII. Pennant used two different prints of Catherine of Aragon to ornate copies of his work: one in his extra-illustrated A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), here, p. 30/2, and another in his extra-illustrated HPWaH, at FRO, p. 220. The latter is described as a print by Hollar.

In Cervantes's novel, The ingenious gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha (2 vols., 1605, 1615), Don Quixote's adventures come to an end with defeat against a young man from his home town on the beach in Barcelona.

George Nassau Clavering Cowper, third Earl Cowper (1738–89), art collector and patron, of whom Thomas Patch made a caricature painting during time spent in Pola, Croatia, in 1760. ODNB.

Drawings relating to Patna in the Indian state of Bihar are listed in Mr Langford, A Catalogue of the Genuine, Entire and Curious Collection of Prints and Drawings … of the late Dr Mead ([London], 1755). They include ‘One Patna drawing of the present Grand Mogul’, ‘Six Patna drawings’, and ‘One ditto after Corregio’s Venus’, and were auctioned by Abraham Langford.
A document in the possession of Henry Penruddocke Wyndham during 1792, and variously described as a plan and a drawing of the city of Beijing (Peking) in northern China.

Charlotte Stanley (née de La Trémouille), countess of Derby (1599–1664), was born in France. A descendant of a prominent French Huguenot family, in 1626, she married James Stanley, seventh earl of Derby. Viewed as a Royalist heroine, she presided over a garrison of around three hundred men at the Stanleys' Lathom House in Lancashire, surviving a siege which lasted for eleven weeks from mid-March 1744. ODNB. Papers relating to the Stanley estates are currently located at the Flintshire Record Office, Hawarden. The reference to Charlotte de La Trémouille in marginalia to letter 1166 is suggestive of an art work relating to her. For a miniature seventeenth-century portrait of her see https://www.rct.uk/collection/421602/portrait-of-a-lady-called-charlotte-de-la-tremouille-countess-of-derby-1599-1664 [accessed 12 December 2018].

At Godshill Church. A plate entitled 'Coffin of Princess Elizabeth' is included in Pennant, From Dover to the Isle of Wight (1801), p. 167. Pennant notes that the drawing, 'made on the spot, [was] obligingly communicated by Richard Bull, Esq.'

See HPWaH, p. 70, on 'Two beautiful half-length portraits of Charles I. and his beauteous queen, both profiles, finely painted'. Pennant notes that 'They are called Vandyck's, but I suspect the artist'. A profile portrait of Charles I and Henrietta Maria, described as 'after Sir Anthony Van Dyck', and a profile of Charles alone, possibly from the studio of Van Dyck, remain at Mostyn Hall today.

rs.title: The Resurrection of a pious family

note.note: Matthew William Peters (1742–1814), portrait and genre painter, and Church of England clergyman. Peters' pastel drawing 'The Resurrection of a pious family', of which several copies and engravings were made (including an engraving by Francesco Bartolozzi) may be the print Pennant mentions in 1205. ODNB; and here [accessed 15 January 2019].

For mention of 'a singular portrait of Sir Richard [Trevor], dressed in black' at Trevalyn, see A tour in Wales (2nd edn., 1784), I, p. 321; and for a watercolour drawing, see Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales (2nd edn. 1784), I, here, p. 320/4.

Francis Drake (1540–96), pilot, sea captain and explorer, whose exploits included a voyage through the straits of Magellan and through the Indian ocean around the Cape of Good Hope. Portraits including oils and line engravings are housed at NPG, BM, NMM. ODNB.

Sir Humphrey Gilbert (1537–83), explorer and soldier. For his final voyage, in 1578, Gilbert received letters patent of six years duration to explore 'remote heathen and barbarous landes'. His final voyage took him to Newfoundland where he claimed territory in the name of Queen Elizabeth. On the return journey Gilbert's ship was engulfed by the sea. ODNB. Several line engravings are housed at BM and NPG.
Illustration on title page of Arctic zoology (2 vols; 2nd edn., 1792), I. It is described in full in the list of illustrations as 'Head of the Elk not arrived at its full Growth'.

This appears on the title page to Arctic zoology (1785), II, and Arctic zoology (2 vols., 2nd edn., 1792), II. In the list of plates in both editions it is described as 'Title-page, the Pied Duck, No 488', and the engraving itself includes the attribution 'P. Mazell sculp'.

Pennant writes of Bantam in the Malayan Isles in Outlines of the Globe: The view of the Malayan Isles, New Holland, and the Spicy Islands. Vol. IV. (London: printed by Luke Hansard; sold by John White, MDCCC), p. 24 and passim. The drawing in question here was a copy by Nicholas Pocock.

note.note: Thomas Baskerville (1630/31–1700), topographer, was born in Sunningwell, Berkshire, and earned a reputation as an eccentric. The portrait of Baskerville discussed by Pennant and Bull may be that upon which a print of Baskerville after an unknown artist, published by George Cruikshank in 1819, is predicated. ODNB; and here [accessed 23 January 2019].

rs.title: eight prints of Bay of Fundy
rs.addName: eight picturesque drawings taken in the Bay of fundy or its neighborhood; the prints; 8 drawings

note.note: The Bay of Fundy is situated between the Canadian provinces of North Brunswick and Nova Scotia, and also touches the New England state of Maine. In ‘Introduction of the Arctic world’, in Arctic zoology (2 vols., 1784–5), I, pp. cxcix–cc, Pennant speaks of the remarkable tides in the Bay, and notes that the coasts in the area ‘exhibit most picturesque scenery’. The drawings of the Bay, copied from Des Barres's The Atlantic Neptune according to letter 1212, do not appear in the published Arctic zoology and must have been additions used in extra-illustration, as Pennant's reference to his 'pastiferous operations' in letter 1215 further suggests.

rs.title: march of General Goddard
rs.addName: march of Genl: Goddard; Goddards march

note.note: For Pennant's account of the fifteen hundred mile long march of General Goddard from Calpy on the Jumna river, to Amedabad, see The view of Hindoostan. Vol. I. Western Hindoostan (London: Henry Hughs, MDCCXCVIII), pp. 67–8.

rs.title: map of the Islands of Shetland
rs.addName: map of the Schetland & orkney isle; Captain Preston's pretty chart of Schetland

note.note: Described as 'a M.S. chart by moses' in 1219, this is evidently a copy of A new hydrographical survey of the Islands of Shetland By Capt Thomas Preston with many improvements and additions and the sailing directions (London. Printed for R Sayer and J Bennett Chartsellers No 53 Fleet Street as the Act directs, 3rd Dec 1781). See here [accessed 24 January 2019].
A manuscript version by Moses Griffith of the 1750 survey of the Orkney Islands carried out by Murdoch Mackenzie, senior (1712–97). See here accessed 24 January 2019].

rs.title: prints of the Bridgewater navigation
rs.note: For the history of the Bridgewater Canal, instigated by Francis Egerton, third duke of Bridgewater, to carry coal from Worsley, now a suburb in Greater Manchester, to the industrial areas of Manchester, and opened in the early 1760s, see <hi rend="italic">ODNB</hi> s.n. Francis Egerton, third duke of Bridgewater; and <ref type="http" target="http://www.bridgewatercanal.co.uk/history/">here</ref> [accessed 24 June 2019].

rs.title: John Lloyd, Caerwys
rs.note: It appears from a letter of 1 June 1781 that Pennant had arranged for a portrait of John Lloyd, Caerwys, to be engraved by Peter Mazell before the appearance of the second volume of <hi rend="italic">A tour in Wales</hi>. This was re-engraved c. 1793, after Lloyd's death. See <ref target="1010.xml">1010</ref>.

note.note: For a watercolour by Moses Griffith of 'Hawarden Castle' see Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales (2nd edn, 1784), p. 94/7; another, unsigned, watercolour appears in Pennant's extra-illustrated A tour in Wales (1778), I, p. 97. These were evidently copied by John Ingleby for Richard Bull's extra-illustrated copy of the first volume of A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778). See 1009.

rs.title: William Pitt [the younger]
rs.note: A line engraving of William Pitt the younger by John Keyse Sherwin, after Thomas Gainsborough, was published by Sherwin and Robert Wilkinson on 15 June 1789. NPG D40236; NPG D40249; NPG D40250.

note.note: A drawing of a silver harp kept at Mostyn Hall, Flintshire, was later engraved by Pennant for inclusion in A tour in Wales 1770 [1773] (1778)), I, p. 434. An image of the harp, still kept at Mostyn Hall is found here [accessed 9 October 2020].
See Wenceslaus Hollar digital collection at here [accessed 9 August 2018].

rs.note: not identified

rs.title: Portrait of Edward VI
rs.note: For oils and drawings of Edward VI (1537–53) by Hans Holbein, the younger, some of which are still part of the Royal Collection, see *ODNB*. A list of paintings at Appuldurcombe compiled by Richard Bull includes 'A very curious \\small// picture of Edward VI. By Holbein. – he is very young, and has a rattle in his hand'. See 'A selection from the principal paintings, cultures, and drawings in the house at Appuldurcombe', CR 2017/TP189/10. Cf. Holbein's 1538–9 portrait of Edward VI as a child, at the National Gallery of Art, Washington, DC @ https://www.nga.gov/collection/art-object-page.71.html [accessed 14 August 2018].

rs.title: Portrait of Henry VIII
rs.note: A list of paintings at Appuldurcombe compiled by Richard Bull includes 'a portrait, on a thick panel of Henry eigth [*sic*]. By Holbein, which Mr Walpole thought one of the best of that king, and \\is probably// original, as it was presented by that monarch, to Sir James Worsley, \\when// governor of the Isle of Wight, after a visit he had made him, at Appuldurcombe park'. The same portrait is listed in an inventory of the contents of Appuldurcombe, dated *c*.1779–81. It is identifiable with a three-quarter length oil on panel attributed to the circle of Hans Holbein, the younger, now kept at Brocklesby Park, Lincolnshire. 'A selection from the principal paintings, cultures, and drawings in the house at Appuldurcombe', WCRO, CR 2017/TP189/10; L. O. T. Boynton, 'Sir Richard Worsley's Furniture at Appuldurcombe Park', *Furniture History*, I (1965), 39–58, esp. 43, 58, n. 13; *ex inf*. Joan Gibbons, Personal Assistant to the Earl of Yarborough. Further on portraits by Hans Holbein, the younger, of Henry VIII, see *ODNB*.

rs.title: Portrait of Frances Howard, Countess of Somerset
rs.note: Frances Howard, countess of Somerset (1590–1632), courtier. Bull's letter to Pennant of 14 August 1787 (*1064*) reveals that the picture at Appuldurcombe was that from which Simon de Passe made his early seventeenth-century line engraving, 'Frances, Countess of Somerset'. See https://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw133675/Frances-Countess-of-Somerset?LinkID=mp04187&search=sas&sText=Frances%2C+Countess+of+Somerset&role=sit&rNo=1 [accessed 14 August 2018]. Further portrait in oils are listed in *ODNB*.

rs.title: head of Walter, Earl of Essex
rs.note: Walter Devereux, first earl of Essex (1539–76), nobleman and adventurer (erroneously referred to in *1061* and *1064* as Robert, earl of Essex). A list of portraits at Appuldurcombe describes this as 'An Head of Walter Earl of Essex 1572. By Frid: Zucchero'. Anonymous oil portraits or Walter Devereux dated 1572 are found at Christchurch Mansion, Ipswich, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York. See 'A selection from the principal paintings, cultures, and drawings in the house at Appuldurcombe', CR 2017/TP189/10; *ODNB*; and https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Devereux,_Walter_(1541%3F-1576)_(DNB00) [accessed 14 August 2018] for a reference to a portrait of Essex by Frederic Zucchero.

rs.title: Portrait of Lady Worsley
rs.note: Frances (d. 1659), daughter of the diplomat and courtier Sir Henry Neville (1561/2–1615) and wife of Richard Worsley (d. 1621). A portrait of her by Cornelius Jansen is included in 'A selection from the principal paintings, cultures, and drawings in the house at Appuldurcombe', CR 2017/TP189/10. See also *Hist P*; *ODNB*; Burke: *Baronetcies*, p. 581; L. O. T. Boynton, 'Sir Richard Worsley's Furniture at Appuldurcombe Park', *Furniture History*, I (1965), 39–58, esp. 43, 58, n. 19; WCRO CR 2017/TP189/10.

rs.title: Portrait of infanta Isabella Clara Eugenia
rs.note: The infanta Isabella Clara Eugenia (1566–1633), Archduchess of Austria. A portrait in oil on canvas attributed to Francis Pourbus, the younger, dated *c*.1598–1600, shows her wearing a large ruff. See https://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/themes/exhibitions/in-fine-style/the-queens-gallery-buckingham-palace/the-infanta-isabella-clara-eugenia-1566-1633-archduchess-of-austria [accessed 14 August 2018]. An engraving by Crispijn de Passe, the elder, shows her in the same costume. See http://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O564577/isabella-eugenia-clara-dg-infans-print-passe-crispijn-de/ [accessed 14 August 2018].

rs.title: 2 large landscapes
rs.note: Several landscapes by Francesco Zuccarelli are noted in an inventory dated *c*.1779–81 of the contents of Appuldurcombe Park. Of these, the two that are best identified with those described by Bull are 'A large landscape, view of the Veronese Mountains with the River Adige' and 'Its companion, a view in Italy'. See L. O. T. Boynton, 'Sir Richard Worsley's Furniture at Appuldurcombe Park', *Furniture History*, I (1965), 39–58, esp. 43.

rs.note: Further on this print, see ar1057.

rs.title: little prints of Enmore
rs.note:
These prints have not been identified but their link to a 'Print of the House of Yvory [recte Yvery]' is through the person of John Perceval, earl of Egmont, a member of this house for whom the country house of Enmore was built ante 1779. See https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1307522 [accessed 15 August 2018]; and for the volume on the House of Yvery
.

rs.note: Carlos Francisco de Croix, marqués de Croix (1699–1756), viceroy of New Spain between 1766 and 1771. For an image see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Francisco_de_Croix,_marqu%C3%A9s_de_Croix#/media/File:CarlosFranciscodeCroix.jpg [accessed 29 August 2018].

rs.note: For Moses Griffith's drawing of the Lleweni bleachery in Denbighshire see Pennant's extra-illustrated *A Journey to Snowdon* (1781; limited large paper edn., 1786) at http://hdl.handle.net/10107/4692660, p. 30.

rs.title: portrait of Sir Henry Lee
rs.note: Sir Henry Lee (1533–1611), courtier, and favourite of Elizabeth I. A portrait by Moses Griffith, engraved by James Basire, was included as frontispiece to Pennant, Of London (1790).

rs.title: Wenlock tomb
rs.note: For mention of the tomb of the prebend William Wenlock (d.1392) at Luton Church, see *The journey from Chester to London* (1782), pp. 397–8.

rs.title: Boreas, from the Temple of the winds

note.note: Boreas, the Greek god of the north wind. The 'Temple of the winds' in which he appears to have been represented here has not been identified.

rs.title: Prints from Olafsen's History of Iceland
The Triumph of Poverty; The Triumph of Riches
rs.note: *The Triumph of Riches* and *The Triumph of Poverty* were large canvases created by Hans Holbein, the younger, for German Hanseatic merchants in London during 1533–4. The originals are lost but several copies of the works were made, including Holbein's drawing for *The Triumph of Riches*. Copies of both were made by Lucas Vorsterman *c*.1624–30: *The Triumph of Riches* is held at the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford (http://collections.ashmolean.org/collection/search/per_page/25/offset/0/sort_by/relevance/object/51118 [accessed 5 September 2018]), and *The Triumph of Poverty* at the British Museum (http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=720463&partId=1&searchText=merian%2C+holbein&view=list&sortBy=producerSort&page=1 [accessed 5 September 2018]). *ODNB*.

rs.title: Print of Sir Wolstan Dixie from painting at Christ's Hospital
rs.note: Sir Wolstan Dixie (1524/1525–94), merchant and administrator, and mayor of London. A portrait of Dixie, dated 1593, is found at Christ’s Hospital, Horsham. ODNB. On James Granger's reference to a head of Sir Wolstan Dixie owned by Richard Bull, see Granger, A biographical history of England, I, p. 250.
